TopicTitle: Make the heat shield fairing flush with the heat shield

Articles.Content:
Currently, when you attach a heat shield to a decoupler, you get that ugly white protruding fairing that covers it and juts out. Can't we just have it so the fairing is in line with the edge of the rest of the stack.

Just an aesthetic issue
Yes. Deadly Reentry has nice looking decouplers for heat shields. Honestly, the stock decouplers in general look terrible (except for engine fairings which look OK).
Ven's stock revamp solves this problem, as well as just about any other part related issue.

Ven's stock revamp solves this problem, as well as just about any other part related issue.

We shouldnt need a mod to make stock not look terrible. Stock should look acceptable as it is, then there are mods for people who want a different aesthetic paradigm.
@Captain Sierra Very true. But the modding community listens a whole lot better than Squad. So for now, we've gotta make do.
I support this suggestion for the stock game.
I posted about this a while ago, so YES, smooth-out the fairings!

yeah, the stock heat shield fairings just seem out of place.

Does anybody know how to disable the heat shield fairings completely in the meantime? they look better without it and I tweak the decoupler beneath it always so it touches the shield, a bit compacter and it looks better when the fairings disappear.
They also don't have to become transparent on mouseover. That's just distracting.

Im in for smooth heatshield fairings!

Any news on this terrible, ugly problem?

Deadly Reentry solved it nicely.

This is actually already solved ... kind of. There are actually two nodes on the bottom of heatshields now. It's a bit of pain sometimes, but if you attach decouplers to the higher node, it simply doesn't have a fairing, instead having the decoupler up close and flush with the heatshield.
Except the decoupler is also too big. That image also shows how awful the stock 2.5m tank textures are.

It causes the heat shield to remain attached to the structure beneath by a thread, even though they are considered separate vessels.
